heading: house leader scorns un tax plan
subheading: house majority leader dick armey comes out swinging against a united nations proposal to tax email and funnel the cash to developing nations.
author: declan mccullagh
text: washington -- talking about internet taxes is one sure way to fluster usually mild-mannered republicans. but a net tax proposed by the united nations, scourge of all right-thinking conservatives? watch out. "every time you turn around, it seems there is another agency or bureaucracy looking to get its greedy mitts on the internet through new taxes," house majority leader dick armey wrote in a letter sent to his colleagues in congress on wednesday.on monday, a branch of the un suggested that world governments should tax the internet to help underdeveloped countries get access to the network. the plan proposes a tax of the equivalent of one us cent on every 100 emails that an individual might send.but the texas congressman said the un's idea is an example of bureaucrats run amok."us taxpayer dollars should not be used to support un reports pushing this kind of redistribution policy," armey said.
